conclusion: Problem involves two objects A and B moving in the same direction with v-t graphs.
Graphs show velocities over time with curves shaped like upside-down U's.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, represented by the slope of the v-t graph.
Slope at any point on the graph gives acceleration at that time.
Red tangent lines on curves indicate slope (acceleration) at points.
For object A: velocity starts at zero, increases to a peak, then decreases back to zero by t1.
For object A: acceleration starts at zero, increases, reaches a maximum, then decreases.
For object B: velocity starts at zero, increases to a peak, then decreases back to zero by t1.
For object B: acceleration starts at zero, increases, reaches a maximum, then decreases.
Acceleration is increasing when slope is getting steeper, decreasing when slope flattens.
For object A: from t=0 to peak, acceleration is positive and decreasing.
For object A: from peak to t1, acceleration is negative and increasing in magnitude.
Acceleration decreases to zero, increases to a negative peak, then decreases back to zero.
Curvature of v-t graph changes indicating acceleration phases.
Tangent lines on object A show slope increasing, reaching maximum, then decreasing.
Tangent lines on object B show similar behavior to object A.
Not straightforward if acceleration is increasing or decreasing throughout interval.
Acceleration is the second derivative of position or first derivative of velocity.
Initial part: velocity increases, slope (acceleration) is positive and decreasing.
